natural problem:
Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$
natural solution: There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "prime a"
and h2 : "prime b"
and h3 : "4 < a \<and> a < 18"
and h4 : "4 < b \<and> b < 18"
shows  "a * b - (a + b) = 119"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "prime a"
and h2 : "prime b"
and h3 : "4 < a \<and> a < 18"
and h4 : "4 < b \<and> b < 18"
shows  "a * b - (a + b) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers between 4 and 18, such that when you multiply them and subtract the sum of the two primes, the result is 119.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 \<le> p"
and h3 : "p \<le> 18"
and h4 : "4 \<le> q"
and h5 : "q \<le> 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "p * q - (p + q) = 119"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 \<le> p"
and h3 : "p \<le> 18"
and h4 : "4 \<le> q"
and h5 : "q \<le> 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "p * q - (p + q) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers between 4 and 18 (inclusive) such that their product minus their sum equals 119.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "(p * q) - (p + q) = 119"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$

theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "(p * q) - (p + q) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find two different prime numbers between 4 and 18 such that their product minus their sum is 119.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: nat and A B C D E :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p ≠ q"
and h7 : "A = p * q - (p + q)"
and h8 : "B = p * q - (p + q)"
and h9 : "C = p * q - (p + q)"
and h10 : "D = p * q - (p + q)"
and h11 : "E = p * q - (p + q)"
shows  "C = 119"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: nat and A B C D E :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p ≠ q"
and h7 : "A = p * q - (p + q)"
and h8 : "B = p * q - (p + q)"
and h9 : "C = p * q - (p + q)"
and h10 : "D = p * q - (p + q)"
and h11 : "E = p * q - (p + q)"
shows  "C = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers $p$ and $q$ in the range $4<p<18$ and $4<q<18$. If $A, B, C, D,$ and $E$ are defined as $A = p*q - (p + q)$, $B = p*q - (p + q)$, $C = p*q - (p + q)$, $D = p*q - (p + q)$, and $E = p*q - (p + q)$, find the value of $C$. The final answer is $119$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p ≠ q"
shows  "p * q - (p + q) = 119"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p ≠ q"
shows  "p * q - (p + q) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find two different prime numbers $p$ and $q$, each greater than 4 and less than 18, such that $p*q - (p+q) = 119$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "is_prime p"
and h1 : "is_prime q"
and h2 : "p \<noteq> q"
and h3 : "4 < p \<and> p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q \<and> q < 18"
shows  "(p * q - (p + q)) = 119"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$

$$ The final Answer is 119

Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "is_prime p"
and h1 : "is_prime q"
and h2 : "p \<noteq> q"
and h3 : "4 < p \<and> p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q \<and> q < 18"
shows  "(p * q - (p + q)) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find two different prime numbers, both greater than 4 and less than 18, such that their product minus their sum equals 119.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "(p * q - (p + q)) = 119"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$

theorem
fixes p q :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p"
and h3 : "p < 18"
and h4 : "4 < q"
and h5 : "q < 18"
and h6 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "(p * q - (p + q)) = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find two prime numbers $p$ and $q$ such that $p$ and $q$ are both greater than $4$ and less than $18$, and $p$ is not equal to $q$. If these conditions are met, then $p * q - (p + q)$ equals to $119$.

theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "4 < p \<and> p < 18"
and h3 : "4 < q \<and> q < 18"
and h4 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "p * q - (p + q) = 119"

fixes p q :: int

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "prime a"
and h2 : "prime b"
and h3 : "4 < a"
and h4 : "a < 18"
and h5 : "4 < b"
and h6 : "b < 18"
shows  "a * b - a - b = 119"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h1 : "prime a"
and h2 : "prime b"
and h3 : "4 < a"
and h4 : "a < 18"
and h5 : "4 < b"
and h6 : "b < 18"
shows  "a * b - a - b = 119"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers, $a$ and $b$, both greater than 4 and less than 18, such that $a * b - a - b = 119$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime a"
and h1 : "prime b"
and h2 : "4 < a"
and h3 : "a < 18"
and h4 : "4 < b"
and h5 : "b < 18"
and h6 : "a \<noteq> b"
shows  "(a * b) - (a + b) = (119 :: nat)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two different prime numbers between $4$ and $18$ are chosen. When their sum is subtracted from their product, which of the following numbers could be obtained? $$
\text A. \ \ 21 \qquad \text B. \ \ 60 \qquad \text C. \ \ 119 \qquad \text D. \ \ 180 \qquad \text E. \ \ 231
$$ The final Answer is 119
 ### Proof
 There are five prime numbers between $4$ and $18:$ namely $5,$ $7,$ $11,$ $13,$ and $17.$ Hence the product of any two of these is odd and the sum is even. Because $$xy-(x+y)=(x-1)(y-1)-1$$increases as either $x$ or $y$ increases (since both $x$ and $y$ are bigger than $1$), the answer must be an odd number that is no smaller than $$23=5\cdot 7-(5+7)$$and no larger than $$191=13\cdot 17-(13+17).$$The only possibility among the options is $\boxed{119},$ and indeed $119=11\cdot 13-(11+13).$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime a"
and h1 : "prime b"
and h2 : "4 < a"
and h3 : "a < 18"
and h4 : "4 < b"
and h5 : "b < 18"
and h6 : "a \<noteq> b"
shows  "(a * b) - (a + b) = (119 :: nat)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers, each greater than 4 and less than 18, such that the product of these two numbers minus their sum equals 119.
